summary:
During 10+ years in Web Development I worked on large enterprise applications, built complex and data-heavy UX and UI, created Design Systems from scratch, built developer tools, worked in platform teams and created solutions in organisations with teams distributed across the entire world.
I used the majority of relevant frameworks and libraries and constantly monitor new ones to be able to choose the best tool for the job.
I contributed to popular Open Source projects, made my own libraries and helped companies grow OSS projects to create awareness, attract talents and give back to the community.
I love working on innovative products, collaborating closely with designers, taking challenging projects, learning and sharing my knowledge with my colleagues every day.
Based in The Netherlands, I have a permanent residence permit (no visa sponsorship needed).

awards.title: RVC Special Prize in Garage48 hackaton
awards.description:
I was a part of a team called "Let's Change". We've made a working prototype of service "HomEx" (Home Exchange) for sharing and renting apartments closer to one's office. Our project was second in the final results and we've got a special prize for that work.

http://garage48.org/blog/garage48-moscow-2013-winning-project-helping-to-learn-guitar-in-an-easy-and-entertaining-way

profile_positions.title: Frontend Consultant

profile_positions.description: Full-time remote job. We make the most advanced trip planner on the travel market that can be also used as a personal time organizer. I was hired as a JavaScript developer with experience in optimization of complex AngularJS applications with infinite scrolls and a large number of UI elements visible at the same time (which is a common source of performance problems in Angular world). Most of the time I do optimization work and rewrite key modules of the application. Also I try to make our frontend team work more efficient by introducing some Agile techniques that can be used in remote teams. More information about my key tasks is in the projects section.
profile_positions.title: Senior Web Developer

profile_positions.description:
Keywords: Agile, Scrum, XP, TDD, Unit Tests, JavaScript, AngularJS, React.js, HTML5, CSS3, SASS, LESS, HAML, Slim, Ruby, Ruby on Rails, Sinatra, RSpec, PostgreSQL, MongoDB, Redis, Solr, nginx, REST, XML, SOAP, XML Signature, NPAPI, Jira, GitLub, TeamCity, Continuos Integration.

I started as a junior Ruby on Rails developer with a Frontend background and worked on e-government services and other enterprise applications. Over time I developed my Backend skills as well as gained much more AngularJS experience to become a full-stack developer and eventually a team lead. Most projects I worked on were closed to public so I can't give any links, screenshots or detailed information.
profile_positions.title: Senior Developer, Team Lead

profile_positions.description:
Keywords: JavaScript, jQuery, AngularJS, Python, Django, PHP, Symfony, WordPress, MySQL, Apache, nginx, Axure, cross-browser, HTML5, XHTML, XML, XSLT, CSS3, Bootstrap, SASS, BEM.

I was a freelancer and worked on many short-time projects. My primary job was to make a frontend part. At first it was only some JS, many HTML/CSS templates and a simple backend based on popular site engines like WordPress. The more I learned the more I got complex tasks including developing small jQuery-based applications, for example specific calculators for consumers, complex UIs to show monitoring data and many others. At the end of my freelancer career I began to use AngularJS that was at the time the best tool for my specific tasks.

I combined my freelancer work with another project called KogdaKuda. It was my first big project based on Django framework that gave my opportunity to learn Python language for web develoment, database design, UI prototyping and many other things. More information about this and other projects is in the projects section.

volunteer_experiences.description: I'm the host in one of the most popular tech podcasts in Russia called RadioJS (radiojs.ru), especially among frontend developers. Together with two other hosts Konstantin Burkalev and Andrey Salomatin we discuss news in a frontend world like releases of new libraries or methodologies, noticeable blog posts from known developers, new conferences and meetups. Usually we talk about our own real experience and try not to give any opinion on things we didn't try ourselves. Also we make interviews with our Russian-speaking colleagues from all other the world. Our primary goals are to give different opinions on complex subjects, to educate junior developers and to tell about local meetups and conferences in Russian cities.

MoscowJS (moscowjs.ru) is one of the oldest and well-known meetups in Russia for frontend developers passionate about JavaScript and web technologies. It was held in Moscow monthly. Nowadays it's online due to the Corona outbreak. I took part in preparing the program of the meetup on a regular basis, also I looked for new speakers and helped them to improve the content of their talks.
